title: Agricultural Supply Delivery Network
content:
Your farming cooperative needs to distribute fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides from the central warehouse (<loc_depot>) to scattered farms (<loc_customer>). Each farm requires a specific amount of supplies (<demand> kg), and your delivery trucks have a maximum load capacity (<capacity>). The goal is to design routes that:  
✓ Never exceed a truck’s capacity while loading supplies.  
✓ Ensure all farms receive their orders in as few trips as possible.  
✓ Let drivers conclude their shifts at the last farm on their route, avoiding unnecessary return journeys to the warehouse.  
This approach reduces fuel costs and keeps farmers supplied efficiently.

title: Grocery Wholesaler Route Optimization
content:
As a food distributor, you must deliver perishable goods like fruits, vegetables, and dairy products from your distribution center (<loc_depot>) to local grocery stores (<loc_customer>). Each store orders a unique combination of items with varying weights (<demand>), and your refrigerated trucks can only carry up to (<capacity>) kilograms. The challenge is to:  
✓ Plan routes that respect each truck’s capacity limits.  
✓ Minimize total mileage to keep delivery times short and fresh produce intact.  
✓ Allow drivers to end their routes at the final store, cutting down on empty return trips.  
Balancing load efficiency and route length ensures cost savings and customer satisfaction.

title: Utility Company Equipment Deployment
content:
A utility provider needs to install new meters and transformers across rural areas. Trucks depart from the maintenance hub (<loc_depot>) carrying equipment kits (<demand> per site) for each job at remote locations (<loc_customer>). Each vehicle has a limited cargo space (<capacity>), and crews must finish at their last assignment rather than returning to base. Key requirements:  
✓ Ensure no truck overloads by exceeding its capacity.  
✓ Prioritize routes that cover the most geographically clustered sites.  
✓ Reduce overall travel distance to lower operational costs and improve service reliability.

title: Catering Service Event Deliveries
content:
Your catering business must transport pre-prepared meals, utensils, and decor to event venues (<loc_customer>) from your central kitchen (<loc_depot>). Each event has specific catering needs (e.g., 100 plates, 50 chairs), and your delivery vans have a maximum weight limit (<capacity>). The goal is to:  
✓ Assign deliveries so no van exceeds its capacity.  
✓ Optimize routes to serve all events with minimal detours.  
✓ Let drivers finish at the last venue, eliminating redundant backtracking.  
This streamlines logistics and ensures timely setup for events.

title: Construction Material Logistics
content:
A construction firm requires delivering building materials—like cement bags, lumber, and bricks—to active job sites (<loc_customer>) from a bulk storage yard (<loc_depot>). Each site demands a specific volume of materials (<demand>), and your trucks have strict payload limits (<capacity>). The challenge is to:  
✓ Avoid overloading any vehicle beyond its capacity.  
✓ Plan routes that efficiently cluster nearby sites to reduce idle driving.  
✓ Allow drivers to conclude their routes at the final site, avoiding depot returns.  
This minimizes fuel use and ensures materials reach all sites on schedule.

title: Floral Delivery Network Optimization
content: Your floral service must deliver bouquets, potted plants, and floral arrangements from your studio (<loc_depot>) to customers’ homes and businesses (<loc_customer>). Each delivery requires a specific volume or weight (e.g., bulk shipments of flowers or heavy ceramic planters). Delivery vans have strict capacity limits (<capacity> cubic feet or kilograms) to avoid overloading. Routes must ensure all orders are delivered without exceeding vehicle capacities, while drivers finish their day at their last delivery stop—no need to return to the studio.

content: A home appliance company needs to transport refrigerators, washing machines, and other bulky items from its warehouse (<loc_depot>) to customers’ addresses (<loc_customer>). Drivers end their shifts at the final installation site, avoiding unnecessary return trips.
